et: borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}bombinātus,{/it} past participle of {it}bombināre,{/it} word of uncertain meaning formed from the base of Latin {it}bombīre{/it} or {it}bombilāre{/it} "to buzz, hum" (in New Latin taken to be synonymous with these words), derivatives of {it}bombus{/it} "buzzing, humming," borrowed from Greek {it}bómbos{/it} {ma}{mat|bomb:1|}{/ma}

Latin {it}bombināre{/it} has had a shadowy existence from the time of Martianus Capella (5th century {sc}c.e.{/sc}), who uses the agent derivative {it}bombinātor{/it} in his {it}De Nuptiis Philologiae et Mercurii.{/it} The 11th century lexicographer Papias glosses {it}bombināre{/it} as {it}conuiciari{/it} ("to utter abuse against, scold, revile"), or at least Papias is thus recorded in an early printed edition (Venice, 1485), which was picked up in Du Cange's dictionary of post-classical Latin, {it}Glossarium mediae et infimae Latinitatis.{/it} An oft-quoted occurrence is in the imaginary book title {it}Quaestio subtilissima, utrum Chimaera in vacuo bombinans possit comedere secundas intentiones{/it} ("A subtle question, whether a Chimera buzzing in a vacuum can devour secondary intentions"), part of a mock library in François Rabelais's {it}Pantagruel{/it} (the first volume, printed ca. 1532, of the Gargantua and Pantagruel novels); the translation of {it}bombinans{/it} is conventional, but Rabelais' meaning is far from certain.
